programs.name: Free Cataract Surgery Project
programs.beneficiaries: Approx. 500 individuals per month (250 surgeries at HASL Eye Hospital, 250 in government hospitals)
programs.date: March 2025 (project start / sponsorship period reported in FY 2024/25)
programs.mini_description: Donor-funded programme to provide free cataract surgery + lens implantation for low-income elders, restoring sight and independence.
programs.description: The Free Cataract Surgery Project was sponsored by the Jeco Foundation (coordinated through Amico Corporation). Reported in FY 2024/25, the project is described as providing around 500 free cataract surgeries per month — roughly 250 at the HelpAge Eye Hospital and 250 at partner government hospitals. The sponsorship supports surgical costs and lenses for low-income elders, contributing to the Eye Hospital’s ongoing mission to eliminate cataract-related blindness among disadvantaged senior citizens. The project and related donor visits and coordination are discussed in the Eye Hospital section of the Annual Report.

programs.name: HelpAge Eye Hospital – 50,000+ Surgeries (Milestone)
programs.donor: Multiple donors; hospital fundraising and in-kind support acknowledged (see donor lists)

budget.amount: Cash & In-kind donations totalling Rs. 1,939,793 (reported for Eye Hospital FY 2024/25)

programs.beneficiaries: 52,249 total cataract surgeries completed since inception (reported by end of FY 2024/25)
locations: HelpAge Eye Hospital, Sinsapa Road, Wellawatte, Colombo 6
programs.date: July 2024 (milestone celebration); cumulative surgeries reported through March 2025
programs.mini_description: Commemorative milestone and hospital operations summary highlighting 52,249 free cataract surgeries to date and hospital capacity.
programs.description: The HelpAge Eye Hospital (established as a full hospital in 2009) celebrated reaching the 50,000+ free cataract surgeries milestone during the year under review (milestone event July 2024). By the end of FY 2024/25 the report records 52,249 cataract surgeries performed since inception. The hospital operates free surgery slots Monday–Thursday (up to 20 free cataract surgeries per day reported) and a clinic day on Friday. The Annual Report notes purchase of a new phacoemulsification machine (2 Aug 2024) and a visiting consultant ophthalmologist (Prof. Harminder Singh Dua, 3 Feb 2025). Total cash + in-kind donations to the Eye Hospital for FY 2024/25 are reported as Rs. 1,939,793. The milestone event included dignitaries (Minister of Health and HASL leadership) and extensive media coverage.

programs.name: Mobile Medical Unit (MMU) Camps
programs.donor: HelpAge Sri Lanka (HASL) with corporate sponsors (e.g., Supreme Global Holdings, others)

programs.beneficiaries: 145 camps in FY 2024/25; weekly camps screening ~150–300 elders; cumulative programme has reached ~500,000 elders since inception
programs.date: Ongoing (145 camps conducted during year ending 31 March 2025); double camps held most Saturdays across year
programs.mini_description: Two mobile medical/eye buses deliver free weekly medical and eye camps island-wide (screenings, spectacles, referral for surgery).
programs.description: HASL operates two Mobile Medical Unit buses that run weekly across the country following requests from Senior Citizens’ Committees and local authorities. In FY 2024/25 HASL conducted 145 eye and medical camps. Typical attendance is 150–300 elders per camp; the Annual Report lists outputs such as 11,449 medical screenings, 15,820 eye screenings, distribution of 12,178 spectacles and identification of 3,604 cataracts during the review period (figures aggregated across MMU and project-sponsored camps). Supreme Global Holdings is noted as a major sponsor (sponsoring 50 MMU camps). The MMU programme is a major frontline service, linking screening to the Eye Hospital and referral networks.

programs.description: The HASL Ayurveda Clinic in Boralesgamuwa provides free indigenous treatment to senior citizens on a weekly basis under the supervision of a qualified Ayurvedic doctor. The Annual Report records approximately 40 elders benefiting each week, totalling around 2,000 treatments in FY 2024/25 and roughly 32,000 patients since the clinic’s establishment in 2004. The clinic forms part of the organisation's integrated care offering complementary to the Eye Hospital and MMU services. (page: 5)

programs.mini_description: Non-residential day-care providing meals, recreation, medical checks and income-generation activities for disadvantaged elders.
programs.description: The H. P. Gooneratne HelpAge Elders’ Day Care Centre (DCC) in Ratmalana offers non-residential day care for disadvantaged elders aged 55+, operating Monday–Saturday. An average of 30–35 elders attended daily during FY 2024/25. The Centre provides breakfast, lunch and afternoon tea (donor-funded), recreational activities (exercise, yoga, indoor games), religious activities, income-generation projects (envelopes, lamp wicks, carpets from rags) whose proceeds are shared among participants, and regular medical/eye clinics. The DCC also organises cultural events, pilgrimages and entertainment for members.

programs.description: HASL's Home Care Service supplied trained carers to assist needy elders with daily living activities. In FY 2024/25 the service provided assistance to 1,889 elders (with 740 new client requests). The report records 172 carers trained and 1,073 monitoring visits conducted; client satisfaction was reported at approximately 70%. The Home Care Division also organised CSR activities (e.g., Poson Poya lunch distribution to road cleaning staff across Colombo, Kotte and Maharagama areas on 21 June 2024). The service is supervised through monthly field visits and supported by donors and internal programme budgets.

programs.name: Sponsor a Grandparent (SaG) Programme

locations: and other districts listed in programme reports

programs.mini_description: HAI-funded holistic support for senior committees: capacity building, livelihood microloans, MMU camps and advocacy for elders’ rights.
programs.description: The Sponsor a Grandparent (SaG) Programme was renewed from 1 April 2024 for FY 2024/25 with funding from HelpAge International (budget GBP 39,629). Key activities included a 3-day residential capacity-building training for 50 National Senior Citizens’ Federation executives (26–28 Nov 2024), leadership and bookkeeping training, an International Day of Older Persons celebration in Kegalle with public awareness activities, 41 mobile medical and eye camps across multiple districts, home-care volunteer training (50 participants, Jan 2025) and livelihood support through microloans (112 beneficiaries received a total of Rs. 1,325,000 to start small income-generating activities). The project emphasized promotion of elders’ rights, community advocacy and strengthening SCC governance.

programs.mini_description: HAI-Global Emergency Fund supported distribution of dry food and essential non-food items to flood-affected older-person-headed families across multiple districts.
programs.description: HASL implemented flood-response activities funded by HelpAge International’s Global Emergency Fund. One GEF project (Project 01) ran June–September 2024 distributing dry food packs and non-food packs (e.g., rice, dhal, hygiene items, buckets, soap, sarongs) to 1,167 families across Western, Gampaha, Southern and Matara districts (detailed distribution tables provided in the report). The report references two GEF projects with combined support reaching a larger total (1,967 families referenced in summary sections). Dry food pack contents and district-level distribution breakdowns are included in the Annual Report. These interventions targeted households headed by older persons and aimed to meet immediate needs after flooding.

programs.name: Flood Response Project – UNFPA (Hygiene Kits for Older Women)

programs.beneficiaries: 1,268 hygiene kits distributed to senior women (Jaffna and Ampara distribution: 634 kits Jaffna, 634 kits Ampara)
programs.mini_description: UNFPA-funded hygiene-kit distribution supporting older women affected by floods in Jaffna and Ampara districts.
programs.description: Supported by UNFPA funding, HASL distributed 1,268 hygiene kits to older women affected by floods across the Northern (Jaffna) and Eastern (Ampara) provinces between December 2024 and March 2025. The report provides a detailed breakdown showing 634 kits allocated to Jaffna DS divisions (Delft, Kayts, Point Pedro) and 634 to Ampara DS divisions (Addalachchenai, Akkaraipattu, Pottuvil). The hygiene kits were part of an emergency response to restore dignity and address menstrual and hygiene needs for older women in disaster-affected areas.

programs.mini_description: Capacity-building grant to strengthen HASL’s humanitarian response capabilities, including international training and follow-up in Sri Lanka.
programs.description: The SHAPE Project (HelpAge International) provided USD 7,949 to strengthen HASL’s humanitarian preparedness and response capacity. Three HASL staff attended a 5-day training in Kathmandu (23–27 Sep 2024) covering project management; upon return they delivered in-country training (11–12 Nov 2024) in finance, monitoring & evaluation and safeguarding. SHAPE aimed to institutionalise improved processes for emergency response and programme management. (page: 17)

programs.description: The HASOP Project (supported by HelpAge Deutschland and BMZ) allocated EUR 133,333.25 for a holistic capacity-building approach targeting marginalised older people and Senior Citizens’ Committees (SCCs) across Southern Province districts (Galle, Matara, Hambantota). Activities included staff training on safeguards and HR, multiple introductory meetings with SCC members across DS divisions, leadership and governance training, and targeted community engagement. Participant lists and district-by-district meetings are shown in the report. The project runs from 1 Dec 2024 to 30 Nov 2025 and aims to strengthen local governance and the empowerment of elders.

programs.mini_description: Longstanding micro-donation tills placed in retail outlets and public spaces to collect small donations — a core HASL fundraising stream.
programs.description: The Tills Project (established 1990) collected micro-donations through physical tills placed in high-footfall retail outlets and public locations. During FY 2024/25 the project recorded a budgeted income of Rs. 7,579,693 and an actual income of Rs. 6,705,856. A placement audit in September 2024 found 2,033 tills in the Western Province, declining to 1,612 active tills by 31 March 2025; 51 new tills were placed in targeted outlets during the year and a QR code system for electronic cash collection was introduced to modernise collections. Top revenue outlets included Cargills, Keells and SPAR supermarket chains.
